title: Charitable consumption: innovation in compassion in Britain, 1870-1912
abstractText:
This study locates in their historical context ways of communicating human adversity and the need to intervene through the exploitation of agency and empowerment arising from new patterns of consumption.

The project explores how, from the 1870s, charities increasingly used consuming, promoted by advertising, as innovative fundraising techniques, and produced empirical knowledge or ‘technologies’ to stimulate donations from the public to humanitarian causes. Notably, charities began to actively market the ‘purchase’ of a commodity as a form of donation whereby the ‘donor’/ buyer received a tangible product in return for their gift. Engaging with developing consumer cultures, charitable organisations were able to negotiate what we now call compassion fatigue and, to generate income for causes without necessarily tapping into a moral or sentimental mentality.

The exploitation of the desire to consume became, during the period under study, a pivotal ‘technology of compassion’ in the armoury of multiple British charitable organisations competing for donors. This hypothesis is located within an historical context where, first, philanthropy for domestic causes (poverty was the most common cause) increasingly competed with appeals for global disasters and, secondly, a vast expansion in print and consumer cultures enabled charities to develop innovative strategies in pitching for donations.
